page.title: 17TYSOE LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The name Tysoe derives from "Tiw's Hoh" or a spur of hillside dedicated to the Saxon war-god Tiw. Evidence from folk memory and historical documents show that a Red Horse was cut in the hillside above Tysoe, giving its name to the Vale of the Red Horse. Research and aerial photography in the 1960s show that three horse figures were cut in the slope called The Hangings above Old Lodge Farm at different times - one of them a huge galloping horse about 100yds x 70 yds. in size. Later figures were cut at Sun Rising Covert and Spring Hill, but none are now visible. There is evidence of two Roman sites - one on Sun Rising Hill, and the other in a field above Middle Tysoe. In the Civil War, Tysoe was billeted by parliamentary troops before the battle of Edgehill.
